content.description: Start on ok to crimpy holds and then slap the corner on the left, progress upwars to crimps again then crux is a small dyno to a small flake. I'm hoping this flake doesn't pop off- I can't tell if it will. Move up with bad to no feet to a nice block for the top out. There is a route here. It's just slightly questionable rock quality and may not survive repeated climbs.Update: dead project. Two critical prices about to break
content.protection: Top rope off one medium and one small tree above.

content.description: Obvious crack witih large open space. Tons of loose rock here. Dangerous. Avoid.
content.protection: top rope or could possibly trad

content.description: Shares holds with broken glass, but shifted just to the right. Crimps and small feet to start, then gain a right hand up to a finger hold sloping left sort of a gaston, and then right hand again, with or without inching feet up, on the top out. Be careful if topping out as some rocks may be loose.
content.location: Just to the right of broken glass

climbs.name: Jean-Michel Basquiat
climbs.fa: I'm guessing this has been climbed before- anybody know? Name of line?

content.description: Probably the best route at graffiti wall .Starts in obvious crack. Hands move up into crimpy moves. Crux into a right finger pocket and then a good flat-topped hold. A little loose rock at the top but not too bad. Â Can be top roped off a couple big pines. This could be done a high boulder as well. Not sure on the rating. maybe harder 5.10. Could possibly be led, but the first pro would be above the crux otherwise you'd deck it.
content.location: Roughly the center of the face.

content.description: large obvious flake that could likely be climbed 5.12? Sounds like a drum- I'd avoid this as the whole flake could pop off. Also looks of loose rock I cleaned on rappel.
content.protection: Top rope or could possibly trad. Danger of entire large flake coming off. Avoid.

content.description: Stand start right crimp and left flat faced hold. Right hand up to sloper. Left hand upside down to finger crack, up to larger holds for top out.
content.location: Obvious crack on the right side of the wall

content.description: Short vertical wall of quartzite. Common joints at 90 degrees to the face creating several climbable routes in and around cracks.Be careful of loose rock and likely weak flakes that will peel off. There is some broken glass near the base as of 7/27/2020.
